[[8 June]] [[1925]] - [[24 April]] [[2018]]) was an English [[Catholicism|Roman Catholic]] theologian and grandson of Sir [[wikipedia:James Murray (lexicographer)|James Murray]] (the founder of the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]''). A personal friend of the Tolkien family (a friendship which contributed to his conversion to Roman Catholicism) since 1944, Murray was entrusted by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] to proofread drafts and manuscripts of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''. Tolkien and Murray corresponded frequently, especially on matters of religion, and several letters to Murray were published in ''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' (letters [[Letter 142|142]], [[Letter 156|156]], [[Letter 209|209]]). He became a Jesuit in 1949 and was ordained in 1959. On [[1 August]] [[1959]], Tolkien served Murray's first Mass, and on [[6 September]] [[1973]], four days after Tolkien's death, he assisted in a requiem Mass for Tolkien in the Church of St Anthony of Padua in Headington, Oxford. He was on the Faculty of [[wikipedia:Heythrop College|Heythrop College]] in Oxfordshire and London since 1963.
